Constable -- David Bomberg -- Leon Kossoff -- John Hoyland -- An interview with David Hockney -- An interview with Anthony Caro -- IV. Art Criticism. Problems of art criticism -- In defence of art.

Originally released by Channel Four (Great Britain), 2014.

Day of the Dead Introduction (3:09) -- Cultural and Religious Blend (3:05) -- Mitla (2:20) -- Aztec and Christian Iconography (2:16) -- Etla Festivities (3:15) -- Ofrendas and Angelitos (3:24) -- Spiritual Communication (3:28) -- Remembering Angelitos (4:00) -- All Saint's Day (2:16) -- Day of the Dead Lunch (2:28) -- Muerteada Band (2:58) -- Shifting Religious Views (3:19) -- All Saint's Night (3:54) -- All Soul's Day (2:05) -- Day of the Dead Dichotomy (3:53) -- Credits: Festivals: Day of the Dead, Mexico (0:31) -- LIBR 251 (0:00)
Access limited to UNC Chapel Hill-authenticated users.

Festivals of life nourish us with ancient rituals in a fast-changing world, covering all facets of the human condition, the changing seasons, weddings, coming of age ceremonies, births and deaths, the worship of gods and the battle against evil spirits. This film showcases Mexico's Day of the Dead celebrations that unite the living and the dead in feasting, dancing and decoration. In Oaxaca City, local artists create sand tapestries and enter an altar competition. Families gather at the public cemetery to clean the graves of loved ones and make offerings. In Etla, muerteadas, or street parades, last all night as rival bands engage in mock battles. Join a local family for a traditional lunch of chicken and mole, and learn about Aztec and Spanish religious customs that blended to form today's Día de los Muertos festival of remembrance.
Title from distributor's description (Films Media Group, March 10, 2016)
Streaming video available via the UNC-Chapel Hill Libraries
I.V. Sertima, Editor, Journal of African Civilizations, Douglass College, Rutgers Univ., New Brunswick, NJ 08903
Some issues have separate titles: Great African thinkers, v. 1 (constituting v. 8, no. 1 of the journal); Great black leaders (v. 9).
Began with No. 1, published January 7, 1926; ceased with 1927, no. 31/32, published in December 1927.
Cf. A izdavalosʹ ėto v Rige 1918-1944 / I︠U︡. Abyzov.
"Illi︠u︡strirovannyĭ zhurnal literatury, politiki i sovremennoĭ zhizni"; added subtitle, <1927, no. 6-16>: "revue russe hebdomadaire 'Novaia Niva'."

Savine Collection copy of 1927, no. 8 bears inscription on caption: "Dorogoĭ odamlennoĭ Poposhi︠e︡ i dorogomu Demʹi︠a︡nchiku--moimʺ pupsikamʺ--na dobrui︠u︡ pami︠a︡tʹ otʺ sestrit︠s︡y-krasavit︠s︡y, to-isʺ [illegible signature]. Fevralʹ 1927-VI."
Savine Collection copy of 1927, no.13 bears name and address of former owner (André Savine's father?) on cover: "Waldemar Savine, 100 avenue Ed. Vaillant, Billancourt (Seine)."
Several Savine Collection copies stitched together bear stamp of "Biblioteka 80-go Ochaga M.P. g. Anʹer."
In Russian, with some stories translated from English.
Description based on: G. 2, no. 1 (1 i︠a︡nvari︠a︡ 1927); title from caption.
Latest issue consulted: 2-ĭ godʺ izdanīi︠a︡, 1927, No 19.
André Savine Collection (University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill)
"Иллюстрированный журнал литературы, политики и современной жизни"; added subtitle, <1927, no. 6-16>: "revue russe hebdomadaire 'Novaia Niva'."

Savine Collection copy of 1927, no. 8 bears inscription on caption: "Дорогой одамленной Попошѣ и дорогому Демьянчику--моимъ пупсикамъ--на добрую память отъ сестрицы-красавицы, то-исъ [illegible signature]. Февраль 1927-VI."
Several Savine Collection copies stitched together bear stamp of "Библиотека 80-го Очага М.П. г. Аньер."
Description based on: Г. 2, nо. 1 (1 января 1927); title from caption.
